newsitem.title: USA: Alaska governor proposes education endowment.
newsitem.headline: Alaska governor proposes education endowment.

text.p: With Alaska's resource-based economy on the upswing and plenty of money in savings accounts, the state should consider setting up an endowment for long-term education funding, Gov. Tony Knowles said Monday.
The Democratic governor said he wanted a plan for long-term education funding to be put before voters in the 1998 general election.
"I think Alaska, more than any other state in America, has the chance to build a long-term, stable plan, and what a great legacy," Knowles said in a speech to the Anchorage Chamber of Commerce.
An education endowment could become a "second permanent fund," he said, referring to a state trust fund established in 1977 when North Slope oil began flowing through the trans-Alaska pipline.
The Alaska Permanent Fund has accumulated assets of $20.5 billion from the state's oil wealth and pays each state resident an annual dividend.
Establishing an endowment to fund education in advance would help Alaska cope with a growing population while insulating school budgets from oil-price volatility, Knowles said.
Education spending accounts for about a third of Alaska's annual operating budget. Knowles has introduced a fiscal 1998 budget of $2.4 billion.
Also Monday, Knowles introduced a bill that he said would simplify and make fairer the formula for disbursing state funds to school districts.
His revised formula includes a $12.3 million addition to be used for rewards to school districts that improve their programs.
"If we're going to put more money into it, we have to get more quality," Knowles said.
That incentive funding would be only the second addition to state education spending in the past decade, with the exception of adjustments for inflation, Knowles said.

Knowles proposed the incentive funding come from a $1-a-pack tobacco tax increase being considered by the state legislature. The increase, added to the state's current 29 cent-per-pack tax rate, would give Alaska the nation's largest tobacco tax and would raise an estimated $42 million a year for the state.
